text.p: Orange Plc, Britain's youngest mobile telephone company, confirmed on Friday that it had launched a new telephone handset that worked on two frequencies -- 1800 and 900 Mhz.

The statement was made amid a report in the Financial Times that Orange's rival, Vodafone Group Plc, was colaborating in trials with QUALCOMM Inc which could lead to the first mobile telephone that would work equally well in America, European and Asia.
Vodafone was not immediately available for comment.
Orange's mr601, which is manufactured by Motorola Inc, will allow customers to roam freely in 50 countries by the end of 1997, the company said.

The telephone, which provides up to 180 minutes of talk time or up to 60 hours on standby under what Orange called "optimum conditions", is expected to appeal especially to border-hopping business clients.
It is retailing at 149.99 stg. Monthly charges and customer tariffs are the same as Orange's single-band offers, a company spokeswoman said.
